query: What are the main methods used in terrorism financing and how do financial institutions detect them?
answer:
Terrorist financing involves diverse methods to raise, move, and use funds, adapting to varying organizational needs, from direct operational costs to broader infrastructure and propaganda [FATF Terrorist Financing Typologies Report.pdf.coredownload.inline, Page 1]. These methods can be broadly categorized by the source of funds and the channels used to move them.

Terrorist organizations raise funds through both legitimate and illicit means [FATF Terrorist Financing Typologies Report.pdf.coredownload.inline (2), Page 2]. Legitimate sources are often abused, such as charities, businesses, and even self-financing through employment or welfare payments, a practice known as "black-washing" [FATF Terrorist Financing Typologies Report.pdf.coredownload.inline (2), Page 2]. Illicit activities include petty crime, organized fraud, narcotics smuggling, and support from state sponsors or operations within safe havens [FATF Terrorist Financing Typologies Report.pdf.coredownload.inline (2), Page 2]. The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) notes that terrorist groups exhibit significant adaptability in acquiring funds [FATF Terrorist Financing Typologies Report.pdf.coredownload.inline, Page 1].

Funds are moved through various channels, including the formal financial sector, cash couriers, trade systems, and alternative remittance systems (ARS) [FATF Terrorist Financing Typologies Report.pdf.coredownload.inline, Page 1]. Charities and non-profit organizations are also sometimes exploited to disguise the movement of funds [FATF Terrorist Financing Typologies Report.pdf.coredownload.inline, Page 1]. Disrupting these financial flows is critical to constraining terrorist capabilities and preventing attacks [FATF Terrorist Financing Typologies Report.pdf.coredownload.inline (2), Page 2]. Financial institutions play a key role in detecting and preventing terrorist financing by implementing Anti-Money Laundering (AML) and Counter-Terrorism Financing (CTF) measures. These include Know Your Customer (KYC) protocols, transaction monitoring, and reporting suspicious activities [FATF Terrorist Financing Typologies Report.pdf.coredownload.inline (2), Page 2]. Enhanced financial intelligence and private sector engagement are also crucial in strengthening global CTF efforts [FATF Terrorist Financing Typologies Report.pdf.coredownload.inline, Page 1].
